body: The issue is that aborted tasks don't build their full reply properly, and the bookkeeping gets messed up.  I'll look into adding a fix to PR #1630.
I believe PR #1630 now has a fix and test.  Can you try it out?

Sorry for the long delay. I'm now using your mergekernel branch, but I can still reproduce this problem. An aborted task still seems to stick to the engine and can't be resubmitted because the hub thinks it's still inflight.
Interesting, can you provide a test case?  I cannot reproduce the error with that branch (which now includes a test that resubmits an aborted task).

I have discovered a general (unrelated) issue with resubmit + abort, due to the fact that resubmit does not create a new uuid.  Unfortunately, I believe you are the only user of either of these features, let alone both together, so it goes fairly untested.
Can you try the mergekernel branch again?  I reworked it a bit, so it should be less likely to have issues.  If it doesn't work, please include a test case for reproducing the failure.

``` python
from IPython.parallel import Client
import time

def run_task():
    import time
    time.sleep(7)

def main():

    client = Client()
    lbview = client.load_balanced_view()
    lbview.track = True
    lbview.retries = 10

    # create 10 tasks
    print("create 10 tasks:")
    async_results = []
    i = 0
    while i < 10:
        async_results.append(lbview.apply(run_task))
        print("Task " + async_results[i].msg_ids[0])
        async_results[i].wait_for_send()
        i += 1

    # sleep 10 seconds
    time.sleep(10) 

    # search for tasks in DB
    print("\nsearch for tasks in DB:")
    tasks = []
    for ar in async_results:
        tasks.append(client.db_query({"msg_id" : ar.msg_ids[0]})[0])

    # stop all tasks which are not yet done
    print("\nstop all tasks which are not yet done:")
    for task in tasks:
        print("Task " + task["msg_id"] + ": ")
        if ("result_header" in task) and (task["result_header"] != None) and (task["result_header"]["status"] == "ok"):
            print("  finished at " + str(task["completed"]))
        else:
            print("  not finished yet. will abort.")
            client.abort(task["msg_id"])

    # sleep 10 seconds
    time.sleep(10)

    # search for tasks in DB
    print("\nsearch for tasks in DB:")
    tasks = []
    for ar in async_results:
        tasks.append(client.db_query({"msg_id" : ar.msg_ids[0]})[0])

    # resubmit all tasks which are not yet done
    print("\nresubmit all tasks which are not yet done:")
    for task in tasks:
        print("Task " + task["msg_id"] + ": ")
        if ("result_header" in task) and (task["result_header"] != None) and (task["result_header"]["status"] == "ok"):
            print("  finished at " + str(task["completed"])) 
        else:
            print("  not finished yet. will resubmit.")
            client.resubmit(task["msg_id"])


if __name__== "__main__":
    main()
```

gives me:

Please re-run with current master.  Your example executes successfully for me, and the condition for the error you are seeing no longer exists in master, nor the mergekernel branch I had suggested you test, which has been merged since the last comment.

Perhaps it is just because this is a toy example, but I should point out that you are performing far too many db queries.

You can replace

``` python
    tasks = []
    for ar in async_results:
        tasks.append(client.db_query({"msg_id" : ar.msg_ids[0]})[0])
```

with

``` python
tasks = client.db_query({'msg_id' : {'$in' : msg_ids}})
```

where msg_ids is the list of all your msg_ids:

``` python
    # single msg_ids list:
    msg_ids = []
    [ msg_ids.extend(ar.msg_ids) for ar in async_results ]
```

The same is true of your abort/resubmit calls as well, which can take a list of msg_ids, not just one.
Thanks for the hints about not calling db_query(), abort() and resubmit() for each single msg_id. I switched back to current master and can't reproduce the problem so far. :)

hooray!

I really want to totally rewrite the docs, so that things like those multi-msg_id calls are clearer.
